text: [Music] stanford university
today's session is on the future of medicine we have um three speakers with us today so david rue who was former
chief medical officer at samsung and currently chief medical officer at microsoft christina farr who's a health
tech lead and investor at omer's ventures and she was also previously a health and tech reporter at cnbc along
with fast company and reuters news and then of course our very own steve chan from stanford school of medicine who is
also at the va health and paul auto so some of the topics that we'll be covering today given that we're in the
middle of a pandemic coven 19 and just general topics around vaccine passports
infectious diseases and pandemics along with changes in technology due to covid
such as telehealth and mental health some topics around ai and unstructured data sources a little bit around mixed
reality and virtual reality given the interest around venture capital and investment opportunities we'll also
cover that component for a little bit as well as the important topic of health
equity as well and just issues of health disparity and access to health care i'll go ahead and start off with a few
questions targeting infectious diseases and pandemics and i know david this is
also your background as well prior um to being at samsung and microsoft and your
specialty area and maybe we can start off with you in terms of vaccine passports being a hot topic any thoughts
you might have in terms of how can and should we develop vaccine passports or should we not think about doing that and
also as it relates to data privacy and information security as well
yeah i think the first thing to recognize is that the discussion is really more focused on health
credentials and allowing consumers and individuals to be able to gain access to those records on a device of their
choice or a technology of their choice and that's a topic that has been long-standing an initiative that many
organizations have been working towards it just so happens that the focus right now is on the vaccinations but
ultimately it will also include test results and it will probably need to also include genomic variants etc so i
think we're going to start seeing a greater emphasis on the the broader look of what type of data do need does
need to be captured and so the first aspect of any type of mechanism where one would use this in a means to provide
some kind of entry or admission into a certain area would
involve the ability for us to issue that type of a certificate what we have been
seeing and actually promoting is the issuance using a common standard and that standard being a smart on fire
standard that allows us to be able to have greater interoperability so that different systems can all communicate
with each other so if you were to receive the the vaccine in any part of the world with any electronic health
record the goal is that you only need to have one type of credential and that
would be understood and readable throughout so that has been a big area of universal consensus that i think most
people would agree is good thing in fact there's an entire initiative that microsoft as well as a variety of other
organizations including some of the leading electronic health record vendors like epic and cerner are part of it's
called the vaccine credentials initiative and that is really actively promoting the use of
the smart on fire standard the second piece though is where it often times gets a bit more complicated because
there's now a sort of a transactional piece where you you'll show the credential and and this software
application uh or program will actually determine whether or not this meets the
criteria for predefined criteria for some kind of entry and that's where you're starting to see a lot more of
these companies come up that are popping that are starting to develop uh what they've referred to or some people refer
to as passports but again really it is what it is just a verification of the credentials against the standard and
then how it's used will be dictated by policy it could be governments it could
be airlines it could be a variety of other organizations in fact we work very closely with many of the governments
across the the globe and i was talking to the health administers within the country of israel and they've been one
of the organizations that are currently using this type of technology and what they're doing is they're enabling this
to enable entry and exit out of the country and into certain facilities but what's
interesting about their their approach is it's not just vaccination but it's also labs and so you so that this gets
to the whole point of there there's probably a little bit more of an over indexing on the vaccination piece you
still need lab results to demonstrate that you haven't been recently exposed and
so what we're seeing now is that there are certain organizations that are starting to adopt this there's been a lot of discussion in
the eu the european union whether or not they will also adopt these type of standards and of course here in the
united states there's been active discussions around that and so i think what you'll start seeing is more and
more people will start recognizing that this could in many ways just facilitate the entry
or enable greater confidence the default is you just these organizations are still going to to require the
documentation it's just going to be a lot more burdensome for individuals to be able to go and carry that paper
document which could be get crumpled up or lost in your pocket or wherever so i i would envision that if and when we see
policies being developed around this people will embrace the digital version of this because it'll be so much easier
and faster and more efficient i'm glad that you mentioned the issue of interoperability of health records since
it's a topic that jason from our class was also interested in touching upon a little bit and really the idea that you
use the records to its fullest potentials the systems do need exchange data with one another um question for
steven christina is why is this so difficult it seems to be an issue that we've talked upon constantly for the
last few years is it really technical limitations or limitations on standards or cost constraints or why is this such
a big issue for just getting these health records to talk to one another in exchange data
so this is one of the big topics i was covering in my reporting career going back to
even right after the the affordable care act when we got some reforms called high
tech that were supposed to usher us into this era of interoperability and unfortunately while
at the time i think a lot of work was done to get doctors to move from paper-based systems to
more digital ones and that was a big accomplishment we just we didn't actually overcome this hurdle of moving
towards interoperability of you know actually having this medical information be freely shared and there's lots of
reasons for that but i think on the rather cynically and i'll just say it like the industry just didn't want to
adopt these standards it wasn't in the financial interest of the healthcare system at the time and so
what you ended up seeing is the government trying to pass all these rules to get kind of companies specifically the vendors to
open up in the health systems to embrace it what you ended up seeing is they would meet the requirement technically
but not the spirit of the law and if you had to share a certain amount of data they would do be able to do that once
and then never again and it was just all kind of things like that that you started to see in response and so we
didn't really solve the problem and and we're still trying to solve it and there's been a lot of movement with 21st
century cures i think has been great and we're starting to see more of an api based approach and now i think the big
hope is that the patient or the consumer will rise up and say this is my information these are my records these
are my labs this is my test results and i should have access to this and we are seeing this more and more within kind of
patient groups and i think that is going to be where we see change it's going to be driven by the patient
and less from kind of the system itself so do you want to touch upon one of the
biggest changes that has happened due to coven 19 which is telehealth and how did telehealth evolve during this pandemic
and also what hurdles do we still face specifically on the regulatory side for
a major adoption of telehealth i i can jump in honestly this is something that we've seen
pretty widespread adoption of telehealth during the pandemic there have been numbers 220 or 200 fold increase in
telehealth visits there's a significant amount of adoption barriers that have been removed many people who were afraid
or even unwilling to try it before i have been doing it and so we've seen some significant strides but at the same
time we've also exposed several of the deficiencies of relying on these technologies first and foremost lack of
broadband access people not with lack of digital literacy and just
uncomfortableness of doing it there's a greater preference in many cases to just simply go within person so i feel like
tremendous strides have been made in terms of adoption and utilization that there's still work to be done and then
the other element is the funding or the the reimbursement and what we saw was an
opportunity for organizations to get paid for basically the services that are provided through
telehealth but the challenge and the big question is whether or not those uh will continue post-pandemic
i think i agree with all of that and i would add that there's been a lot of hype during this pandemic about telemedicine and a lot of
folks especially in the venture community are really excited about it i think there's also a growing recognition
that it is just one tool and a toolkit and there's lots of other ways in which
we can engage with patients including home visits and we don't even need in some cases video visits it could be as
simple as a landline or even an sms there's lots of ways that i think we can
think about interacting between kind of doctors and patients or providers and patients and
so as we look to the future i think there's a sort of growing recognition that we need to use all of these and it should
be the patient's preference that that drives it in some cases that a video
visit might make a lot of sense and in others maybe that patient does need to come in and we need to accept that
there's a whole range of tools here that we can be deploying and so that's how i think about telemedicine is just it's a
technology which is a vehicle for delivering care versus the care itself
you would love to hear any additional thoughts you might have on this topic and also in general given your focus on
mental health what are some of the changes that we have seen and new innovations we've seen due to covid and
do you think that we can truly replace psychotherapists with a computer program in the future
yeah i think that telehealth over the past year has really opened up a lot of opportunities really opened up a lot of
people provider of providers eyes particularly in psychiatry my specialty there have been
a lot of traditionalists and old-fashioned thinking and leadership positions
that have encouraged basically face-to-face visits and essentially with telehealth it's really shown that it's
like essential just for everyone's protection and a lot of staff prefer it too
and we've i can't speak for the veterans affairs in this current capacity but i know that it's been wonderful to recruit
and retain talent for psychiatrists and other providers who are otherwise
difficult to recruit in say very expensive costs of living areas
so i think that some of the hurdles that we still have yet to face certainly with the reimbursement that we've discussed
but also not and also the certainly the connectivity issues just imagine how sometimes we have netflix buffering and
and low resolution videos but also for mental health specifically trying to
piece together all the parts of the continuum of care and trying to see if some of it can be done
without having a human involved or for instance education component or having a
follow-up automated follow-up but i think that there still will be a place for human involvement because
there's going to be that attachment where someone wants to talk with to talk of a human but it just depends on which
how severe um your illness might be or how much engagement you might have so i think there's going to be a lot of
variety it's just opening up a lot of different options for us so i'd be remiss if we didn't touch upon
ai and david some of our earlier conversations more broadly the topic of unstructured data sources and
very hot techniques nowadays microsoft buying uh nuance the speech recognition firm for about 16 billion dollars and
curious on your thoughts in general maybe you aren't able to speak about the acquisition directly yet but the role of
voice user interfaces for healthcare and how we should be thinking about unstructured data sources like voice and
text yeah if you take the broader context of natural language processing and
understanding how we can take these unstructured forms and provide some structure and context to it i'll start
with voice voice has been an incredibly powerful opportunity for us to
understand if we can do voice to text but then not just simply get it to text but understand the contextual
understanding of the terms so once you actually understand that you can then organize it into a clinical note into
different formats and then integrating it into the medical record and that essentially is what microsoft in
collaboration and partnership with nuance had done for actually for the past couple of years we've been working
on this and then we launched a product called dax or dragon ambient experience which is essentially the ability to do
that in the setting of a clinical visit we also attached that to microsoft teams so this was available for virtual visits
and so this opportunity to be able to apply this in the real world was super exciting in fact we we have
more recent data that suggests or that that shows that the amount of documentation has actually decreased the
amount of time that doctors are spending with patients by 50 and it's also increased the throughput
by about 30 percent so it's already demonstrating significant value in in a
in a topic or an area that has just been an incredible pain point for clinicians the ability to remove that and not have
to have either the clinician do it or a scribe do it it's just been an incredibly powerful opportunity but
there's also another element to that which is once you actually understand the context of the terms and the words
that are being said we can actually start doing real-time decision support and start looking for opportunities to
improve quality safety regulatory adherence or even prior authorizations and so that's going to even further
enhance the value of how we can apply this there's another element for natural language processing where there's also
been significant advancements and that's in the area of text analytics and some of the things that we have been spending
time trying to do is develop algorithms and ai tools that will allow us to be able
to similarly understand the context of what's being said so we can do smarter
types of searches and what i mean by that is we can search through medical literature like the full text and the
abstracts and look for studies that have shown that a particular
genotype with a particular cancer it has a certain outcome with when given a
certain treatment that's the type of stuff that would require clinicians to find do these public searches and spend
hours reading the articles and trying to sort it all out or rely on some kind of
a published meta-analysis but we have the ability to do that type of information searches real time and then
now imagine also being applied that applying that to like progress notes and text notes and things that come in that
completely unstructured that have tremendous amount of information so what we're now doing is
we're expanding the amount of available data sources that we can to deeply understand the individual and where they
are on their journey which is going to help us to develop and refine some of our predictive algorithms
christina i love your thoughts in terms of what are some of the major obstacles to implementing ai and machine learning
in healthcare is it is one of the challenges for instance that we talked about healthcare data being so difficult
to share in exchange and the fact that it's so highly fragmented is that one of the major obstacles or are there other
hurdles from the technical side or yeah i think there's a lot there's a lot to this on the investing front we often see
ai slash medicine companies coming out of israel and the reason for that is
because they have this incredible healthcare system which is very capable of pulling together medical information
quickly and they and there's a strong willingness there to share it for the purposes of kind of data analysis and ai
but the problem with that is in israel you have a very specific population that
doesn't tend to include a lot of minorities and we see some but not enough where you could come up with a
data set that would be directly applicable to population say in the us and other parts
of the world and so i think we weighed into this issue here of medical bias which we see a lot and we see
because i think humans are fundamentally biased we see it in the algorithms too but then you also end up with issues
like we don't do enough medical research to incorporate say women and that also gets baked into these
algorithms and women may experience for instance kind of heart attacks differently than men and in those cases
what happens when the algorithm isn't built to recognize those symptoms and you end up with a bunch of kind of apps
that where a woman would type in her symptoms and it wouldn't necessarily direct her into the emergency room in
time so i think those are some of the kind of ethical questions that that we're facing and then there's also this
issue of just the medical system that the physicians have have been told time and time again over the
course of several decades that here is this kind of ai breakthrough coming from silicon valley that's going to
revolutionize the way that you you practice and in many cases that's turned out not to be true and it's been
part of a hype cycle and so now a lot of the doctors that i talk to are quite skeptical when they hear about a new ai
company and i think there's a lot to prove here and companies like microsoft are very aware of this and are
approaching with caution and i think creating technologies that are starting to impress doctors at least that's from
what i'm hearing but there have also been cases like with ibm watson where it was just i think if you followed that
whole saga it turned out not to meet the the great promise that was being offered so i think we just need to tread
carefully as entrepreneurs when we approach kind of these providers with these claims and and we have to be able
to back them up with evidence i'm glad you're touching upon the topic of health equity as well david i know
that you talked briefly about broadband access and would love to hear your thoughts david in terms of how we find ways to
advance vaccine equity and how this in general speaks to the broader issues of health disparity that we have in our
system yeah this is a really timely topic obviously the big emphasis has been get
as many vaccines to in as many arms as quickly as possible and that continues to remain a primary goal but in the
process we are leaving behind the most vulnerable the highest risk individuals who will as we continue to open the
gates further to allow for more entry of participants including younger kids are
going to get left behind and unless we develop alternate pathways to enable
these individuals to be able to get the vaccine and i think the current approach that if you look at what we've done in
terms of providing vaccines availability through retail clinics and through community health centers gets us to that
last mile but we may actually need to go to the last inch and what i mean by that is
we're going to need another push because we are we work with many organizations across the country and i'll give you an
example lausd los angeles unified school district they're one of our key
strategic partners we've been helping them with the return to school effort we've been enabling testing for the
students as well as the faculty which is extended to the family members and now at vaccinations what's happened is
within la the community health centers are all saying we've got all this vaccine and no
one's coming and think of that we talk about how we're running out of vaccine and we're so lit but in certain parts
we're finding that individuals are just not going or not interested in going and what we have to do is we have to
understand that there has to be more than just simply providing access and this ties into a deeper issue of who has
the long-standing trusted relationships with those individuals and what we've learned in talking with many of the
folks that basically work in this space is that it's not
kind of healthcare providers are certainly on the list but it's not we're not tapping into the full range of folks
that are out there and so i what we've learned is not-for-profits schools churches these are all organizations
that need to be engaged in this process and so part of what we're now looking to do is form public-private partnerships that
allow for an opportunity to enable and empower these organizations to be able to deliver vaccines and other health
services into these underserved communities and to do this in a way that allows us to be able to go beyond
covered activities and potentially now to health screenings and to health maintenance it's an exciting opportunity
for us to be able to start rethinking some of the models of care that allow us to be able to deliver care more
equitably to these populations steve i would love your thoughts on the
topic of health equity and specifically are there investments in technology that address minority mental health for
instance those with limited english proficiency or those with difficult ailments or diseases
i think that's an area of need certainly limited english proficiency has certainly relied very heavily on persons
within the community who understand the nuances for the ways of immigration the
cultural history and certainly just the language itself in in some of the research and the projects
that we've been looking at with of speech recognition and lep patients there's not the there's
not a lot of activity it seems in this area that's certainly one area for instance can we get a
physician or a provider who speaks that person's language and it
can be very a challenge right i think that also with health equity certainly
not just the broadband access but we've talked about how in our last certainly our last class 5g
it would be nice to have like high quality streaming video so that we can see as many of the nuances during a
mental status exam we call it to see someone's motor activity to see how someone's walking maybe even notice if
they have any any sort of contraband or bottles and such in the back background where they are living so i think that it
can be something that we could help with better technology and certainly better technology access i'd say a lot of the
folks i'm reaching out to only only are able to really connect by phone and have
incredible challenges getting videos set up so there's a lot of work that can be
done to bridge certainly bridge the gap one more thing i just realized too is uh we actually have something called
a digital divide consult digital divide referral where we have social workers
who reach out to veterans who are lacking in either the webcam or
the computer or even the wireless connection and they'll give them a wireless hotspot attached to an ipad or
combined with an ipad so that they can do video visits and i think that's helped quite a bit and why not why can't
we not roll that out to everybody so that's there's a lot of work that certainly can be done
so i know a topic that a lot of students in the class wanted to cover was just around investing in health care and
investment opportunities chrissy as the investor on our panel what are some of the verticals and trends that are
popular right now that you might be looking at related to health tech and related to that what are some areas that
have been overhyped as well yeah gr these are great questions i'm fairly new to the to the venture side i've been
around for enough time to get a good sense of what my day job is going to be
like and so far at least it's been fab so i'm happy to share some of the the themes that we've identified because as
i was going into this new role i had a list in my mind and nothing has really changed since then so the definitely my
top priority at the moment is behavioral health so i really appreciated hearing some of steven's comments and i think
the reason that we want to do something there is because it's it's really shown us during the pandemic that this need
that we have to say i would call it a crisis we have a crisis of mental health in this country and we don't have
sufficient access to providers there's so many people that need help that can't get it even here in
the bay area anyone who's tried to access a therapist in recent months i know i have and i couldn't find anyone
who would take my insurance it was a weeks-long process and eventually had to give up and that's with insurance that's
with resources i i just it's hard to even imagine what it's like for for everyone else who isn't deeply embedded
in the healthcare system to begin with so i think that's a big reason and then the other issue that we're facing there
is just the fact that someone like stephen a psychiatrist there's only 5 000 being graduated every single year
and more than that retiring so if you look at where we're going to be in the next 10 years it's an we're
going to be in a place where there's so few providers that can treat just this growing storm of patients that that need
care and so i think the sort of big question on everyone's mind now is is what can we do about that short of kind
of training a lot more psychiatrists and mental health providers which i think we absolutely need to do is there a way
that technology can play a role is there some way in which we can make the existing pool of providers able to
access more patients than before and so that's the question that we're looking into and
you know i personally would love to do something for kids and teens in that space because there's so little for
those groups and i think for college students for high school students and even younger there's a lot of data
showing that with every year that passes there's more and more people that are suffering from anxiety and depression and numerous
other things that where they're just not getting help so i think those are some big things that i'm looking into now
another area that i think is really underserved that i would love to make an investment is in women's health and
having just had a baby i've seen you know firsthand that there's just so much that we need to do i'm
i've had i had the baby two months ago i've had one medical visit since then it's and that was because i have
insurance i only saw a doctor six weeks postpartum and there's so much for those
who've had babies there's there's so much that can happen in the first few months that it's just shocking to me that i've just been essentially just
dropped off at home and told to figure it out and it isn't like that in other countries we have one of the the highest maternal mortality rates if not the
highest in in the developed world are where the us is on par with latvia and oman
so i think we have a lot of work to do there as well and i'd love to it's another area where i just i continue to
meet founders and see a lot of you know really promising companies that are looking to address some of these
problems there's a lot more but i'm always there and happy to answer more questions
david i would love your thoughts related to that around mixed reality i know microsoft hololens is a big project and
i bring it up because i think as investors oftentimes what drives our investment decisions is also what the
big players are doing and what's the next 16 billion dollar acquisition that you're going to make i would love to
hear from you in terms of how you're thinking about using mixed reality for improving healthcare and
i think microsoft has done a few things around this already i'll give you an example to show you the
potential opportunity with mixed reality we showcased this at one of our recent events it was a case study in which a
physician a surgeon in mount sinai was helping a surgeon in uganda perform the
surgery and traditionally one thinks of you know telemedicine and being able to guide them but what was unique about
this was the surgeon in uganda while looking through the hololens on the surface of the the body
could see the surgeon in sinai outline exactly where the incision
needed to be and they followed through and he just basically followed along it's almost as if you had the person
right there next to you showing you even better because they're actually writing on the patient in a virtual pen
this is an incredible opportunity for us to start rethinking what's possible
relative to how we can use these newer technologies and and there's a significant amount of obviously consumer
use cases and other business use cases for hololens but within healthcare one of the great opportunities is how we can
transform medical education to scale individual skills such as we talked
about stephen and his needing to scale and clone stephen more of him but we we
also need to do that outside of the us as well and get more healthcare providers there are many folks that just
need basic skills and training around doing procedures as well if you were thinking about emergency procedures
chest tubes and in endotubial intubations and things like that what we
can do is we can actually start rethinking how we can train individuals to more advanced procedures there's this
concept in healthcare it's called c1 do one teach one i'm not sure if you've heard of that but essentially what it
means is you have to see a whole bunch of these types of procedures then you have to do one with someone watching you
and guiding you and then eventually you get to the point where you're a teacher to do that it requires a lot of
people to see a lot of different things and there's not just not enough people to mentor and or
individuals to be able to try things on you can actually go and accelerate that dramatically with the use of these tools
so we could rethink how we can expand and scale the medical training and then the second piece is the the virtual care
element being able to actually do procedures and do things that were traditionally difficult to do in person
or virtually just like we can do virtually in person and that's going to create an opportunity when you combine
that with some of the advancements on digital health and being able to get more biometrics we literally can start
thinking about having a much more intimate encounter with either a clinician or a
patient with the data and the all the aspects that make it something that would be viewed as essential in terms of
coming in could now potentially be something that we could think of as being doing virtually so we're really
starting to push the boundaries of what's possible because of the fact that we've got new platforms new data sets
that are coming in and it's all driven by ai and a large part of that is the technology that underlies what we're
trying to build within our devices i like that phrase c1 do want each one um one of the questions and topics that
popped up from spencer in our class was also just covering thoughts that you guys might have in
terms of sectors that are promising for investors that don't have meaningful clinical expertise and then also a
fallout from one of alex's questions is related to due diligence around health tech startups and given a lot of times
the innovation novelty of these concepts how do you actually conduct that diligence so maybe christina we can
start with you and then steve would love your thoughts as well i can weigh in on the diligence question
given that we just completed a big diligence process i'm happy to walk everyone through that
so i think it might be somewhat surprising to folks here because it definitely was to me but a lot of the
the diligence that we end up producing in the you know form of a investment memo that you present to
the whole partnership is in our at least for my fund it's a written document so it's essentially telling a story and
that does include some numbers and analysis of course but a lot of it is driven by primary research so if you're
looking at a health tech startup states in behavioral health you want to do a clinical evaluation where you would
reach out to somebody like stephen and get his um perspective on the company and the board of space and you would
probably talk to a dozen or so folks like that at least who could give you a sense of whether or not this would
medically be viable and then you would also want to diligence the team so find out these founders good leaders what
kinds of things have they done previously would they be able to build a great team and depending on how kind of
late stage the investment is you might start due diligence as well beyond the founders your early executive team cfo
the cto what do people think of them who know them intimately and then you would look into the broader space to create a
market map where does this company fit in if it's in mental health and you would look at lots of other mental
health companies what kinds of exits have they had what kind of funding have they raised and then you think through
possible outcomes for the the company that you're investing in would it be sold to a microsoft in a most likely
scenario or is this a potential ipo and why and and then you go to your your partnership and you have to make a case
for this company i think a lot of investors would say that it's all about kind of financial modeling and
i have no financial background at all and i'm learning as i go but a lot of it
is storytelling you have to be able to convince your team that this is a company that we need to get behind and
that this is a company that can adapt that can potentially pivot if needed nobody could have been able to
financially model what would have happened during the pandemic this past year that would have been crazy and
impossible so a lot of it again is you have to be able to do that storytelling and i think that's why people with
humanity's backgrounds as well as stem backgrounds can add a lot of value to to a fund
besides reading uh david's linkedin posts and reading chrissy's sub stack newsletter the sources i get certainly
would be a lot of the industry reports that even stanford's uh graduate school of business and the stanford library has
access to that can be incredible source to help figure out who are other players in the market how big is the market
certainly and that's all accessible through certainly the stanford library subscription that you have
also having a wide network of colleagues and a lot of folks who are here are
going to be superheroes and everyone has a superpower which is just so incredible and such a gift and so we each have our
own stories to tell and can learn from each other but also in the future when we're learning about the markets and the
industries too and some of the things that i think would be promising for the future
particularly within behavioral health one of them certainly would be anxiety conditions there are a lot of apps that
will address things like just you know mild anxiety mild depression your sort
of bread and butter sort of psychiatric cases but there's a whole unaddressable set of folks who have just
been silently suffering quietly and not thinking that anything could help them
so things like phobias for instance we had talked about virtual reality earlier the virtual reality mixed reality there
are some companies who are working on things to expose people we call it exposure
therapy where we expose someone to something that's super stressful or
in varying doses of stress and i think that could be that could really relieve people some people
suffering that's one and then certainly folks who are i was reached out by a
member of the press at 1.4 my take on a video game therapist
and they were saying is this ethical for someone to be reaching out to video gamers on twitch and discord and
one of the things i've i realized is that this for many gamers for instance they just have they may have a lot of
things that they just have not been able to address and or reach out to or haven't
felt comfortable with i'm thinking of things like video game addictions behavioral addictions certainly the
